transcripts.text: What impact has the Brexit vote already had on the UK economy?  There is context to the question, of course.  Jaguar Land Rover says it's extending a shutdown in production in April because of potential Brexit disruption.  Deutsche Bank is moving 400 billion euros of balance sheets assets to Frankfurt.  Two insurance giants are moving to the European Union.  AIG is moving to Luxembourg, Chubb's moving to France.  They say explicitly because of Brexit.  Panasonic and Sony are moving their headquarters to Amsterdam because of Brexit.  I can actually go on, but you take the point.

Not only take the point, but if you actually explore what that is about, and I don't blame any of them, it is not about Britain being outside with a deal or inside the EU.  What it is about is uncertainty.  And right now, this morning, in Newcastle, there's a businesswoman going to work, she owns her own business, she employs 20 people, she pays tax, she's got her house on the line.  She is a typical businessperson in the United Kingdom, with great respect, not JLR or all the banks you just reeled off, but that is the core of British business.  And what they've got is uncertainty, they've got lack of stability, and they cannot predict where they are.  so what's the one thing they won't do is risk any more investment in their business till they know where they stand and then you can touch the bottom of the pool they're swimming in.  what is killing?  this is not brexit.  it is the uncertainty created by 650 people in the house of commons who are fundamentally as a political class letting down the united kingdom.
But they're doing that, some of them, they say.  Not necessarily, they wouldn't say letting down it, but they are concerned about getting the right deal.
I have to tell you, principle is the last refuge of a scoundrel.
No, but in all seriousness, Panasonic and Sony aren't going to move their headquarters back.
No, I completely agree.  We're in violent agreement here.
We have got significant losses.
What I'm trying to say to you is, it is not whether Brexit happens, it is the uncertainty that has been created by nothing happening.

But there was always going to be this period before a deal was done because it's complicated.  Liam Fox said... No, of course there is.  Liam Fox, who's meant to be in charge of helping us get these trade deals, said it was going to be extremely simple to get a Brexit deal.  And he was wrong.
Well, not only was he, he was probably right at the time when he said it, but he's wrong now.
Even I, I can tell

you, even I, having been on the inside of trade deals and in the House of Lords and watching this as a crossbench peer, I don't do party politics, even I, a couple of years ago, thought that the nation had spoken, the country would get together and they would formulate something that really worked.  And on that basis, Liam Fox was right at the time.  What has happened is the Remainers, and especially the establishment elite, have set about sabotaging Brexit.
I I think that's an incredibly lazy way of categorising people.
No, it's not lazy.  No, it's not lazy.
The establishment elite, you are fuelling hatred against people like Anna Soubry, for instance, who falls into this category of people.
Why are you using words like hatred?  I'm not fuelling anything.
Well, people are calling her Nazis outside of Parliament.

In other words, the way you ever take a position that doesn't conform with the norm, for some reason I'm fuelling hatred, am I?  But you're saying the word sabotage and you're calling them elite.  Well, they are.  I'm only calling it, well, it might be politically incorrect, but it is true.
I'm not saying it's politically incorrect, but you are also getting rid of the notions that they believe, just as strongly as you believe, that they want the best deal for this country.
No, a lot of them don't want to leave the EU.
Well, that might be what they think is the best deal.
And so, therefore, what they're trying to do is stop the execution of the will of 17.4 million people.
But what about MPs like Nick Bowles, who now faces deselection in his own party, purely for even trying to say, we need to take no deal off the table?
I'm trying to get you to what you actually said, which was Liam Fox was wrong.  What Liam Fox was at the time.  And I said, I genuinely believe...

Hang on, we have a clip of you telling Andrew Neil.  Can I play this clip?  Yes, of course.  You told Andrew Neil on the Sunday Politics programme in 2016 that not one job would be lost due to Brexit.

I stand by it.  I stand by it.  There are many arguments that stay in, and there are many arguments that come out, but the one thing that we've got, we ought to kill this canard now, is that not one job in Britain is at risk because of EU membership.  Not one.  Not one.  Because there would be.
